history.content:
CS 188 imo is not a light workload class anymore, it is actually a pretty high workload. The exams are pretty challenging, you have long project deadlines every other week, you also have a long electronic homework every week as well. Not to mention the written hw's which are extremely time consuming. I've never taken math 53 and i've taken data 100, 188, and many other eecs classes and have done fine w/o it.

A "light" upperdiv could maybe be databases or maybe even 170 in that the material is hard but you only have 1 hw a week.

CS 188 imo is not a light workload class anymore, it is actually a pretty high workload. The exams are pretty challenging, you have long project deadlines every other week, you also have a long electronic homework every week as well. I've never taken math 53 and i've taken data 100, 188, and many other eecs classes and have done fine w/o it.

A "light" upperdiv could maybe be databases or maybe even 170 in that the material is hard but you only have 1 hw a week.

children.subject:
I have not taken 186 but have heard from others it is "relatively" light, perhaps someone who has taken 186 can shed some light on the weekly workload? 

If not, you can always compare the previous/current course websites to see their workloads, even searching "186" on this piazza page can help you gauge the difficulty/workload of the class. 

Current 186 website: https://cs186berkeley.net/ taught by Prof Hug and Ball (Both of whom are outstandingly great lecturers) 

186 archives: http://www-inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs186/archives.html

Relevant reddit posts: https://www.reddit.com/r/berkeley/comments/eh37fb/cs_170_vs_cs_186_workload/

As far as 170 is concerned, you do have a project towards the end of the course but it is typically only worth a small amount of the grade (this semester it's worth 5%). The weekly homework can be really challenging, however if you have a good study group (which is always a good idea in any class) it shouldn't be unreasonable for the most part. For example, we had a homework a couple weeks ago that was REALLY difficult and about half the class dropped it LOL...but other than that it hasn't been too crazy. I would say CS 170 is really comparable to CS 70 if you have taken that.

186 isn't taught by Hug and Ball. It's W186 which is an online lecture format by Hellerstein.

Though next semester is the first time it's being taught in person (in a long time)

170's workload is highly variable. Most of the time spent in 170 is just thinking about how to solve homework problems, and the time required to do this varies wildly from person to person. I agree with anonymous calc, it's very comparable to 70.
Thanks Anon. calc! This was VERY helpful. Out of CS170 and 186, which one has more weekly work (i.e. projects/psets etc.) in your opinion?

<md>+1. There are 6 projects now (0-5). And I would say it has more coding than 61B. Not only you write more code but there are also a lot of tricky edge cases you need to consider, which are tested in hidden tests. In addition to the projects, the exams are also getting harder. The curve is very nice tho.</md>

186 is not light. It has significantly increased in workload from previous iterations. The "homeworks" are essentially projects, of which there are 5. All of these projects (excluding project 0: setup and project 1: SQL)  pertain to building a certain aspect of a database, starting with record indexing, then join operations+query optimization, and locking. While the material is not too conceptually challenging, the amount of material covered is quite dense. 186 now has a workload similar to 61B.
Unfortunately, it's not offered in the Fall :( Thanks though!

I'd like to provide another perspective, I almost completely disagree with the student answerer here. It depends on what you personally are good at, but from my experience, 188 was the easiest upper div (workload-wise) in comparison to 170, 186, and 161 (the only easier one I've taken being 168). I took 188 last semester for context. 

I thought the 188 electronic homeworks were reasonable in length and the projects were straightforward for me if I understood the material.The written homeworks were also reasonable when I took it, but this may have changed since they were completely new. I would not describe any components of the course as being time-consuming. I guess my frame of reference is that I was recruiting + taking 186 and 16b concurrently, so relative to those it was much much nicer. I do agree that the material taught in 188 is challenging, and exams are challenging as a result. 

In comparison to 170 and 186 specifically, I thought that the material in 170 was a bit more difficult than 188 and I spent way more time on problem sets each week, but a benefit was that it was only psets and nothing else. For 186, the material is more straightforward than 188 but I spent way more time on projects whenever there was one released - it's pretty bursty in terms of workload.

But of course, your mileage may vary. I haven't taken 53 or DS 100 but from what I've heard, sounds like a solid schedule with 188 + recruiting.

history.content:
Hi, I'm a sophomore planning to take this in fall2020. I've taken all the lower divs (except math 53 obviously). I'm also going to be heavily recruiting next semester -- is this an okay combo (I'm not great at Math)? Can you also recommend another light upperdiv CS/DS class if I do data 100 in the summer?

Thanks!
history.subject: Data100 + Math53 + CS188 + recruiting
